Janet Finch-Saunders AM, Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, addressed the concerns raised by the committee regarding the need for a public awareness campaign to raise awareness of the change in the law, stating that it was important for the public to be aware of the implications of the law change. She also highlighted the importance of ensuring that the public understands the impact of the Bill and the need to ensure that it is implemented in a way that is consistent with the Welsh Government's objectives. However, the Deputy Minister emphasized that the Bill was not intended to create a new criminal offence, and that it should not be seen as a new offence, but rather as a change to the existing law. The Deputy Minister also highlighted that the bill was not meant to create any new criminal offences, but to provide an opportunity for the government to address the issue of parental consent and ensure that parents are not penalised for failing to comply with the new law. In response to the concerns of the committee, the Minister for Children and Families raised concerns about the lack of transparency in the Bill, particularly in relation to the implementation of the legislation, and suggested that the government should consult with the Children (Equal Protection from Assault) (Scotland) Bill, which is currently being debated in the Scottish Parliament, to determine whether it is appropriate for the Bill to be implemented in Wales. The Minister for Education and Skills agreed with the committee on this issue, and agreed that it would be appropriate to consult with both the Scottish and Welsh Governments before implementing the Bill. I believe that the Scottish Government has the right to regulate the Bill in accordance with the Scottish Bill, and I am confident that they will be able to do so in line with the requirements of the Scottish bill. Furthermore, the Scottish Ministers must take such steps as they consider appropriate to promote public awareness and understanding about the effect of section 1 on the abolition for the defence of reasonable punishment. I think we always need to bear in mind that what the Bill does is remove a defence to an existing criminal offence. And in this context, it doesn't make sense for this Bill to contain a provision requiring the provision of information about how a person may raise concerns if it appears to them that a child is being physically punished. As I set out in my letter to this committee responding to recommendation 15 on this point, safeguarding is everyone’s business, and, as now, the public have a role in highlighting to relevant services if they are concerned about a child. I wish to speak to amendments 1A to 1E, which relate to the duty to promote awareness, as well as amendments 1B and 1C. I don't think it's necessary for the Government to set out specifically the topics that need to be covered in the awareness-raising campaign, as is suggested in amendments 1C, but I do believe that it's important that the awareness campaign be comprehensive, well planned, well-organized, and well-coordinated, and reach out to all those people and all those communities, and understand how to respond to it.

The WJEC does provide what's required in a regulatory sense, and there are two things there—the specification, which tends to be very comprehensive in providing guidance in terms of drawing up a programme of teaching, and also exemplar assessments, which include marking, and those go to the regulator before they are published. The WJec also do invest a great deal in resources that we produce digitally in both languages simultaneously. Each new course has substantial teaching guidance, which includes a lot of useful information for teachers and pupils. And we run a professional development programme for teachers that is free of charge when courses are new, and then annually there is some charge for those events. Indeed, the regulations as they stand in Wales, Northern Ireland and England preclude examination bodies from having commercial links with providers of textbooks. So, that is one point that we noted as something that needs to be considered for Wales as we move forward, whether it would be possible—. As we are not talking about examination boards competing with each other in Wales for GCSE and A-levels, in passing, that was something that I would want to suggest may deserve review. At the moment, these tend to be England-based—Hodder Education and Illuminate Education, for example—and then the Welsh Government does provide funding to the Welsh-language versions for those textbooks. Philip Blaker, chief executive of Qualifications Wales, and Emyr George, associate director general qualifications, discussed the role of commercial publishers to provide textbooks. Now, that's something that needed to be looked at in the future, as there was a need for different models for how that might be achieved and also, potentially, around a paradigm shift in what's expected of those materials.

Hefin david am: So, let's start with the early years, because we know that there's a lot of work to be done when it comes to the provision of early years services in Wales, and we need to make sure that we have a system in place to ensure that children have the best possible start in life, and that they have the support they need at the start of their life. julie morgan am: Absolutely, because it's important for parents to have a good start in their children's lives, and it's also important for children to have the opportunity to learn from their parents, so it's really important for them to be involved in their child's education and to be able to support them in their early years. So, we're working closely with the local authorities and working with them to understand how they can best support children in their first few years of life. And, of course, we want to support parents in their time of need, but we also want them to know that we're there for them, and they can come to us for support. sian gwenllian am: And you've just said you want to simplify that, particularly with regard to the availability of funding and the way these things connect from the birth of a child into school? How will simplification look, and what will happen? jo-anne daniels: We're not at the stage of being able to say what it will look like at the moment but we're looking at ways of simplifying, because I think it's absolutely right, it is a very complex system because it has grown up from all different routes. We have got pathway projects in eight local authorities, including Swansea, Newport, Blaenau Gwent, Neath Port Talbot, Swansea, Ceredigion, Pembrokeshire, and Swansea, who have been working with us to look at how all of those services are currently delivered in their local area and whether they can reorganise those services to improve accessibility, to improve take-up, but essentially to improve the efficacy of those programmes in terms of supporting children, but often, obviously, in supporting children you have to support families too and support the home. So that can also help with the development of the children, so, we really see it that our plans are for both parents and children and we believe that a high-quality, early-childhood education and care system can provide that.

meilyr rowlands: I think that there is a lot of work to be done, and we have a lot to do, but I think it's important to recognise that we need to be careful not to lose sight of the fact that there are many different types of children who are eligible for free school meals, and it is important to identify those who are not eligible, and to ensure that they receive the support they need. llyr gruffydd am: Because the research by Ipsos MORI and the Wales Institute of Social and Economic Research, Data and Methods has shown that there's some kind of blurring—I think that's the term that they use—in terms of who is eligible. I think what we've found is that the most effective schools—the ones that really do make a big difference to this cohort of students—are the ones that do that most effectively. In terms of what schools are doing with the grant, we have given evidence to you of the kinds of things that they are doing. They are tracking progress of pupils, they are trying to improve attendance, they're trying to work with families and the community in general, and they're doing work specifically to improve how children are doing in exams, in key stage 4, specifically—a lot of funding is being spent on that—improving the confidence of students, taking students on extra-curricular activities, improving literacy and numeracy. I was in a conference for headteachers last week, where there was new data being discussed, and that data showed the progress of children from a certain point, year 6 tests, and the data showed that there was a significant improvement in the performance of children in the first six months of the school year. So, we look at the relative performance of different groups, including boys and girls, free and non-free, ethnic minorities and ethnic minorities, but we also look at performance of more able pupils in particular. That's not to say that the targeting is working perfectly still, and I think we are seeing examples where the targeting isn't going just to children who receive free school meal meals, but it has not been evaluated well. However, we do feel that schools are using the PDG effectively. One of the shortcomings that we often identify is evaluation, because part of our strategy is always to identify where there are weaknesses, but actually to point schools in the direction of where they can find a solution.

It further notes that rent, mortgage and utility payments are due at the end of each month, putting countless Canadians at risk of losing their housing. They've made sacrifices and gone above and beyond to make the lives of their neighbours better and to keep our communities safe. It would be impossible to list everyone who has emerged as a community hero, but I'd like to highlight a few, like Lily, an eight-year-old from Elgin who raised funds for her local food bank by building and selling squirrel picnic tables, and Louise Boardman from Spencerville who's making masks for long-term care facilities and selling others in support of the Breast Cancer Action centre. It is the people of LeedsGrenvilleThousand Islands and Rideau Lakes that make it so great. Chair, the Indian Act enshrined racism into Canadian law in 1876, and, through residential schools, the child welfare system, our legal system and our police, we criminalized and tore apart indigenous peoples. The deaths of Chantel Moore and Rodney Levi and the assault on Chief Allan Adam are recent examples of systemic racism within the RCMP. Anti-black racism has resulted in more young black men being jailed, children being streamed or excluded from schools and negative police interaction due to profiling. It's now time to reimagine and rework our institutions, starting with our police. andranne larouche (shefford, bq): Thank you, Mr.Chair. The first petition reflects the outrage of my constituents at the ever-expanding order in council from the government banning more and more firearms. I'm here to present two petitions containing hundreds of signatures on the issues of the treatment of Falun Gong practitioners by the People's Republic of China, particularly the practice that's alleged of involuntary organ harvesting. The second petition is from residents throughout SaanichGulf Islands concerned about what was, at the time this petition was submitted, a future problem. It remains an issue, and I present it on behalf of petitioners who wish the government of Canada not to put public funds into purchasing or maintaining the Trans Mountain pipeline or towards any expansion of the pipeline. I would like to remind members that any petition presented during a meeting of the special committee must have already been certified by the clerk of petitions. For members participating in person, we ask that they please come and drop the signed certificate off at the table once the petition is presented.

Hefin david am: Thank you, Kirsty. Kirsty, it is important to note that this is the first time that we have had to deal with a pandemic in Wales, and it is essential that we focus on the health and well-being of children and young people, and we need to ensure that they have access to the necessary care and support. Hefin David am: I would like to ask that Kirsty williams am clarify that the government is not planning to relax any of the restrictions that are currently in place, and that they will continue to be in place until the end of the pandemic, and they will only be relaxed when it is safe for the public to return to school and when they are confident that the health of their children and their families is in the best interests of the Welsh Government and the wider public. kirsty Willams am: We will need to take a lead from our scientific and medical advisers, and I want to also say that we are working on a four-nation basis and keeping in very close contact with my counterparts in Northern Ireland, Scotland and England. But we're also looking beyond the United Kingdom to approaches to education in the face of this pandemic. So, recently I was able to talk to educationalists and Ministers in Iceland, other parts of Europe, North America, South America and Australia. And it is really heartening and humbling to see the way that they've responded to this crisis. And there are teachers, teaching assistants, and many others, who are helping our children and families to keep learning at home. And we also have to look at—and it's been paraphrased quite a lot today—if we are looking at certain groups of children accessing more education within a school setting, which groups they should be. And, finally, how do we operationalise that? How do we make those settings as safe as they possibly can be, and what do we tackle some of the difficult challenges of everything from ensuring that we would do social distancing in the context of education, school transport issues, how you would avoid people gathering at the school gate, for instance? So, there are very practical issues that would need to be considered and thought through very, very carefully before we could return, before what we could see is a move from where we are now to the next phase of education and new approaches to what schooling may look like. But, again, I must be absolutely clear to you, members of the committee, and to people watching: it is not feasible, in this sense, to start to discuss reopening schools when we haven't had the necessary testing in place for the majority of the population. And doesn't it convey a mixed message that we're starting to relax some of these restrictions when, in reality, the restrictions are still in place and still need to being in place robustly? Kirsty Williams Am: First of all, thank you very much, Siân, for that important question. Secondly, we will have to consider any decision to have more children returning to school. It is the responsibility of me, as the Minister, and indeed of the wider Government, to begin to think about planning for the future. But I have been absolutely clear: we are not moving to an imminent change in how education is operating at the moment. And I am also very clear that should we be given the opportunity to see more children in our schools, I will only do that when it's safe for me to do so, when I've been given the reassurances that it will be safe for them to return.
